subject: Dogmatic or Heuristic?

messageBody:
Cedric Beust wrote:

<snip />
> Don't be dogmatic about testing: test whatever you think can break. And
> it's okay if it includes private methods.

This brings up an interesting question -- at least, for me.

Well, two, I guess.

First: Where is the line that divides "being dogmatic" from "trusting a
heuristic"? In this case, it was "test only through the public
interface", which is a heuristic I follow, because it generally leads me
to a better design. (I'll omit the reasons, because the community has
written about them at length. Google is your friend.) Cedric, who seems
not to follow that heuristic, wonders whether doing so is dogmatic, and
rightly so.

I looked up "dogma" at dictionary.com and got this definition:

"An authoritative principle, belief, or statement of ideas or opinion,
especially one considered to be absolutely true."

And "heuristic":

(adj.) Of or relating to a usually speculative formulation serving as a
guide in the investigation or solution of a problem

(n.) A heuristic (adj.) process or method.

So the dividing line appears to be the notion of "absolute truth". This
leads me to recast the question as:

Where is the line that divides "absolute truth" from "sensible default"?
In other words, I only test a private method if I am in a situation
where I have to. What makes this stance dogmatic, rather than heuristic?

Just an open question for the community to consider.

The second question is perhaps more of a comment than a question. I
think that when a novice asks us a question, it's OK for us to provide a
simple, dogmatic-sounding answer. This person is learning, and is
therefore not well-informed about the consequences of the choices he has
in front of him. As a result, we have a responsibility to suggest the
course we think is right and ask him to try it so he can learn the way
we did. In this case, a little dogma doesn't hurt. Notice, though, that
it's dogma from the learner's perspective, and only due to a lack of
experience. For me, at least, it's a heuristic. :)

Incidentally, I only bring this up because we tend to see dogma as
negative, and I don't see why that must be. That said, perhaps we ought
to ask more questions before giving answers....

Take care, everyone.
